milestones.title: Prenatal Vitamins
milestones.shortDescription: Daily prenatal vitamin with folic acid
milestones.details: Take a prenatal vitamin daily throughout pregnancy. Look for one with at least 400-800mcg of folic acid, iron, calcium, and DHA. Folic acid is especially important in the first trimester for neural tube development.

milestones.title: First Prenatal Visit
milestones.details: Your first prenatal visit typically includes a physical exam, blood tests, urine tests, and often a dating ultrasound. This is a great time to discuss your medical history and any questions or concerns.

milestones.title: Dating Ultrasound
milestones.shortDescription: Confirm due date and check heartbeat
milestones.details: The dating ultrasound confirms your due date by measuring your baby. You'll also get to see or hear the heartbeat for the first time! This early ultrasound helps ensure accurate dating for future screenings.

milestones.title: First-Trimester Screening
milestones.shortDescription: NT scan + blood test for chromosomal conditions
milestones.details: This combined screening includes a nuchal translucency (NT) ultrasound measuring the fluid at the back of baby's neck, plus a blood test. Together, they screen for Down syndrome and other chromosomal conditions with about 85% detection rate.

milestones.title: NIPT (Cell-Free DNA)
milestones.details: A simple blood test that analyzes fetal DNA circulating in your blood. It screens for Down syndrome, trisomy 18, trisomy 13, and can determine sex with high accuracy. This is optional but may be recommended based on age or risk factors.

milestones.title: Anatomy Scan
milestones.details: This detailed ultrasound checks baby's organs, spine, limbs, and overall development. The sonographer measures bones, checks the heart chambers, brain structures, and more. You can often find out the sex at this appointment!

milestones.title: Glucose Tolerance Test
milestones.details: You'll drink a sweet glucose drink and have your blood drawn an hour later. This screens for gestational diabetes, which affects how your body processes sugar during pregnancy. If the initial screen is positive, a longer 3-hour test confirms the diagnosis.

milestones.title: Tdap Vaccine
milestones.details: The Tdap vaccine (tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis) is recommended between 27-36 weeks, ideally early in this window. It helps your body create antibodies that pass to baby, protecting them from whooping cough in the first months of life.

milestones.title: Rh Antibody Screen
milestones.details: If you're Rh-negative, you'll receive a RhoGAM injection around 28 weeks to prevent your body from developing antibodies against baby's blood cells. This is important if baby inherits an Rh-positive blood type from dad.

milestones.title: Group B Strep Test
milestones.details: A simple swab test checks for Group B Streptococcus bacteria. About 25% of women carry GBS, which is harmless to you but can be passed to baby during birth. If positive, you'll receive antibiotics during labor to protect baby.

milestones.title: Hospital Bag Ready
milestones.shortDescription: Pack your bag for the big day
milestones.details: Pack your hospital bag with essentials for you, baby, and your support person. Include comfortable clothes, toiletries, going-home outfits, phone chargers, and any comfort items. Having it ready gives peace of mind as your due date approaches!

milestones.title: Weekly Appointments
milestones.shortDescription: More frequent check-ups as due date nears
milestones.details: Starting around 36 weeks, you'll have weekly appointments to monitor you and baby closely. Your provider will check baby's position, your cervix, blood pressure, and discuss signs of labor to watch for.

babyDevelopment.highlight: Tiny embryo implants in the uterus
Nose, mouth, and ears starting to form
Heart beating strong, tiny limbs forming
All essential organs have begun to form
Fingers and toes are no longer webbed
Baby can open and close fists
All organs formed, can make a fist
Baby may be kicking! Can you feel it?
Baby can swallow and has taste buds
Eyes formed but irises still lack color
Eyes can open, brain developing rapidly
Brain growing rapidly, can regulate temperature
Baby can track light and process information
Full term! Brain and lungs mature
